text.p: Solidere shares hit their highest level in more than a year on Thursday and brokers said expectations of a dividend declaration on May 27 were helping to stimulate demand.
Solidere A rose to $11.75 from Monday's $11.5 and B rose to $12 from $11.5 amid heavy demand totalling 735,275 shares.
Brokers said the prices were the highest since January 1996 when Solidere, Lebanon's biggest company, still traded its shares on the private Beirut Secondary Market.
It switched to the Beirut Stock Exchange last September and the private market no longer operates.

"Demand for Solidere shares seems to be a trend preceding the distribution of dividends before the end of May and that is raising the price," Tania Hajj, a broker for Arab Finance Corporation told Reuters.

The rise of the shares on the Beirut market also follows a 50 percent surge last week in the price of Solidere's GDRs SOLAq.L on the London Stock Exchange attributed to purchases by U.S. and European emerging markets funds.
The Solidere rise helped the LISPI and BLOM general indices rise 1.18 percent and 2.45 percent to 88.64 and 1013.19 respectively.
The LIBX bank index also rose 1.08 percent to 139.75.
Bank of Beirut rose to $3.5625 from $3.5 and Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce rose to $17.25 from $17, bringing its rise since listing last December to 53 percent.
Among the four industrial shares only Eternit rose, reaching $1.9375 from $1.875. Ciments Libanais was steady at $1.2812 and there was no trade in Ciments Blancs and Uniceramic UNIN.BY.
